legalStatus.loanTypeAllowed: Payday Loans (via Credit Access Business Model)
legalStatus.restrictions: Must operate as licensed Credit Access Business (CAB)
legalStatus.notes: Texas uses a unique CAB model where the credit access business (broker) is licensed, not the actual third-party lender. The CAB charges fees for arranging the loan, which are not subject to state caps. This creates one of the least restrictive payday lending environments in the United States.

regulatoryBody.name: Office of Consumer Credit Commissioner
regulatoryBody.address: Finance Commission Building, 2601 N. Lamar Blvd., Austin, TX 78705

regulations.maxLoanAmountNotes: No state limit. City ordinances in major cities limit payday loans to 20% of gross monthly income.
regulations.maxAPRNotes: Texas does not cap APR for CAB transactions. Typical APRs range from 400% to 700%+. Example: A $300 loan for 168 days can have $1,008 in CAB fees alone (730% APR).
regulations.rolloverLimitNotes: No state limit on rollovers. City ordinances limit to 3 rollovers/renewals with 25% principal reduction each time.
regulations.coolingOffPeriodNotes: No state cooling-off period. Some city ordinances define renewal as loan within 7 days of previous loan.
regulations.databaseNotes: Texas does not maintain a statewide payday loan database.

fees.originationFeeNotes: CAB fees are typically calculated as a percentage of the loan amount, often 10-25% per payment period.
fees.latePaymentFeeNotes: Late fees are not capped at the state level.
fees.cabFee: Typical 10-25% of loan amount per payment period
fees.cabFeeNotes: The CAB fee is the primary cost to borrowers and is separate from interest charged by the third-party lender. Interest to the lender is typically 10%, but CAB fees often exceed $1,000 on a $300 loan over 6 months.

rightToRescind.notes: Consumer may cancel contract within 3 days after signing without penalty. Must provide written cancellation notice.

prohibitedPractices: Threatening or pursuing criminal charges for bounced checks absent fraud, forgery, or theft
Failing to comply with Fair Debt Collection Practices Act

consumerProtections.noCriminalProsecutionNotes: Lenders cannot threaten or pursue criminal charges against borrowers for bounced checks or non-payment, except in cases of forgery, fraud, theft, or other criminal conduct.

collectionRules.repossessNotes: Payday loans are unsecured. For auto title loans (separate product), repossession is allowed.
collectionRules.garnishmentNotes: Texas law prohibits wage garnishment for consumer debt. Wages may only be garnished for child support, back taxes, and defaulted student loans.
collectionRules.homesteadNotes: Texas homestead exemption protects primary residence from debt collection.

cityPageContent.headline: Understanding Payday Loan Laws in Texas
cityPageContent.intro: Texas residents in {{city}} should understand that payday loans are legal in Texas through licensed Credit Access Businesses (CABs). While Texas has minimal state-level restrictions, {{city}} may have additional local ordinances that provide extra consumer protections.
keyPoints: Texas allows payday loans through licensed Credit Access Businesses (CABs) regulated by the Office of Consumer Credit Commissioner (OCCC)
There is no state cap on interest rates or CAB fees - typical APRs range from 400% to 700%+
You have the right to cancel your loan within 3 days of signing without penalty
Lenders cannot threaten criminal prosecution for non-payment (except for fraud or theft)
Your wages cannot be garnished for payday loan debt under Texas law
Your home (if declared homestead) is protected from debt collection
Always verify your lender is licensed at occc.texas.gov before borrowing
cityPageContent.cityOrdinanceNote: If you live in Austin, Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, Fort Worth, El Paso, or one of 20+ other Texas cities with local ordinances, additional protections may apply including loan amount limits (20% of gross monthly income) and rollover restrictions (maximum 3 with 25% principal reduction each).

warningBox.title: Important Cost Warning
warningBox.content: Payday loans in Texas are among the most expensive in the nation. A typical $300 loan can cost over $1,000 in fees alone, resulting in APRs exceeding 700%. Consider alternatives such as credit union loans, payment plans with creditors, or nonprofit credit counseling before taking out a payday loan.

cityPageContent.disclaimer: This information is provided for general educational purposes only and should not be construed as legal advice. Payday loan laws and regulations change frequently. The information presented may not reflect the most current legal developments. For the most accurate and up-to-date information, contact the Texas Office of Consumer Credit Commissioner at (800) 538-1579 or visit occc.texas.gov. If you need legal advice, please consult with a licensed attorney in Texas.
